SECTION 1 — INTRODUCTION

1.1 Purpose of This Manual This manual defines the complete set of engineering principles, mathematical models, calculation rules, AI prompting logic, safety constraints, dispatch strategies, and evaluation procedures required to model and size commercial and industrial battery storage systems. It is designed to be ingested by AI systems and used to support calculations for peak demand reduction, energy arbitrage, demand response participation, backup power analysis, incentive qualification, and integrated multi-measure optimization. All content in this document is deterministic, non-hallucinatory, and based on real-world engineering principles, utility program rules, and industry-standard best practices.

1.2 Background and Intent Battery modeling is traditionally performed by specialized engineers using a wide range of tools including load modeling platforms, financial spreadsheets, utility-specific tariff engines, or simulation tools like NREL SAM. This document translates these engineering requirements into a fully text-based form so that AI tools can replicate this reasoning without ambiguity, inconsistency, or hallucination. The intent is to give an AI system the capability to: Perform engineering-grade modeling from minimal inputs. Suggest optimal battery sizes based on user goals such as ROI, DR eligibility, payback, or bill reduction. Identify utility program incentives automatically. Calculate savings using deterministic formulas, not estimates or guesses. Prevent incorrect or physically impossible modeling results. Explain results to non-engineers in plain language. Adapt to varying data quality and automatically fill missing details using established inference logic.

1.3 Types of Battery Systems Addressed This manual applies to: Lithium iron phosphate (LFP) BESS systems Nickel manganese cobalt (NMC) systems AC-coupled BESS DC-coupled BESS Modular containerized battery systems Behind-the-meter commercial batteries Front-of-the-meter DR-only batteries (with proper modifications)

Not all logic applies to all chemistries, but the overall modeling approach is valid for most commercial systems installed today.

1.4 Inputs Required by the Battery Model The model can operate with high-quality or low-quality inputs. Ideal inputs include: Interval data (kW every 15 minutes or 5 minutes) Monthly billing data (kWh, kW, $) Utility tariff structure including: Peak, part-peak, and off-peak energy rates Non-coincident demand charges On-peak demand charges Seasonal variations Battery specification data from a library including: Nominal power (kW) Nominal energy (kWh) Usable energy fraction Round-trip efficiency Allowed C-rates (charge and discharge) Allowed depth of discharge Cycle life and warranty constraints Inverter rating Site metadata including: Address Climate zone Building type Square footage Operating schedule User-driven goals such as: Maximize ROI Minimize payback Maximize peak shaving Qualify for a specific DR program Qualify for SGIP, CEFO, OBF Find the smallest battery that meets a target demand reduction

1.5 Modeling Assumptions When inputs are missing, the model will rely on inference rules defined in this document. The model must explicitly state which assumptions were applied. The model must never fabricate data that violates physical laws. The model must always disclose uncertainty when assumptions are used.



SECTION 2 — BATTERY FUNDAMENTALS (EXPANDED)

2.1 Power (kW) Battery power defines the maximum instantaneous rate at which the battery can deliver or absorb energy. It is primarily limited by the inverter but may also be restricted by internal battery chemistry, thermal constraints, and manufacturer-defined discharge limits. Peak shaving depends directly on power rating because demand charges are based on instantaneous or interval demand.

The model must always compare the following: Battery nominal power Battery continuous discharge rating Inverter continuous AC rating Inverter short-term power rating Warranty discharge limit

Peak shaving uses the lowest of these values.

2.2 Energy (kWh) Energy defines how much total energy a battery can store. It determines how long the battery can maintain a specific discharge rate. For example, a 100 kW / 100 kWh battery at 100 kW can discharge for 1 hour. Batteries with high energy relative to power perform better in long-duration events such as extended demand charge windows or DR events requiring more than one hour.

The model must never assume energy equal to nominal energy; it must account for usable capacity and degradation.

2.3 Usable Energy and Depth of Discharge Actual usable energy depends on: Depth of discharge limit (e.g., 80–90 percent) Battery temperature Age of the battery Inverter conversion losses Cell balancing overhead

Usable energy equals: Nominal energy multiplied by usable fraction.

Different manufacturers define usable fraction differently, such as: Total battery capacity minus reserved buffer Full usable window defined in warranty Charge windows for solar clipping

The model must always track usable energy separately from nominal energy.

2.4 Round Trip Efficiency Round-trip efficiency is the product of charging efficiency and discharging efficiency. The model must use round-trip efficiency to calculate arbitrage savings and, in some cases, DR energy requirements. Efficiency reduces delivered energy and directly impacts economics.

Typical sources of losses: Inverter conversion DC cabling Internal resistance Cooling systems Power control system inefficiencies

The model must not assume constant efficiency. For example, LFP batteries often peak at 94 percent at moderate C-rates but fall to 85 percent during high C-rate discharge or low temperatures.

2.5 Charge Constraints Charging limits may be lower than discharging limits. Many batteries restrict charging to 0.5C even if discharging can be 1C. AI must check manufacturer charge limits before modeling arbitrage that requires full recharge within off-peak windows.

2.6 Inverter Rating and Derating Inverter rating is a hard limit on power. The model must always use AC-side inverter power when calculating peak shaving and DR capacity.

Inverters also derate due to: Temperature Altitude Voltage limits Overload protection

In extreme heat, a 100 kW inverter may be limited to 80 kW.

The model must apply derating rules when environmental data is available.

SECTION 3 — C-RATE, DISCHARGE DURATION, AND PHYSICS (EXTENDED)

3.1 Formal Definition of C-Rate C-rate is the ratio of a battery’s discharge power to its energy capacity. C-rate determines how quickly a battery would fully discharge if it maintained rated power for the entire time.

C-rate = Power_kW / Energy_kWh

If P is discharge power and E is usable energy, the theoretical discharge time (ignoring losses) is:

Duration_hours = E / P Duration_hours = 1 / C

3.2 Derivation from First Principles Consider a battery with energy density U (Wh) and a discharge rate I (A). Power is P = V × I Energy is E = V × Q

C-rate is defined at the cell level as:

C = I / Q

Mapping cell-level C to system-level C requires pack-level voltage and capacity normalization. For AI purposes, system-level C is sufficient.

3.3 Why C-Rate Determines Applicability Battery applications have fundamentally different constraints: Arbitrage: Requires sustained multi-hour discharge Peak Shaving: Requires fast ramp AND 1–2 hours of output DR: Requires sustained output with recovery time UPS: Requires extremely high C-rate for seconds-long output

3.4 AI Rules Governing C-Rate AI must enforce these rules:

Rule 1: If duration < peak-event duration → penalize or reject battery Rule 2: If C-rate > OEM warranty max → reject battery Rule 3: If C-rate < minimum required for use-case → reject battery Rule 4: If inverter_kW < battery power → use inverter_kW for C-rate Rule 5: If temperature derating applies → adjust C-rate downward Rule 6: Always recompute C-rate using usable energy, not nominal energy

3.5 Typical Manufacturer C-Rate Limits LFP: Charge: 0.5C Discharge: 1.0C

NMC: Charge: 0.3C–0.5C Discharge: 0.75C–1.25C

3.6 Degradation Impact of C-Rate Cycle life decreases approximately exponentially with increasing C-rate:

Life_fraction ≈ exp(−k × (C_rate / C_nominal))

Where k ≈ 1.0–1.5 for most chemistries.

3.7 Real-World C-Rate Constraints Batteries may advertise 1C capability, but real operational limits reduce this: Thermal derating at high ambient temperature Voltage sag under high current Inverter current limits PCS firmware caps DoD and SOC window enforcement

AI must factor these.



SECTION 4 — PEAK DEMAND SHAVING ENGINE (EXTENDED)

4.1 Identifying True Peak Demand Peak demand is the highest measured demand interval in a billing cycle.

PeakDemand = max(interval_kW)

AI must: Ignore anomalous single-interval spikes Identify multi-hour plateau peaks Determine whether the peak is HVAC-driven, process-driven, or random

4.2 Peak Event Segmentation To model shaving, AI must identify the “peak event window” — the contiguous time span around the max demand during which demand exceeds a threshold (e.g., 90% of the peak).

EventWindow = intervals where kW >= 0.9 × PeakDemand

This gives event duration: EventDuration = length(EventWindow)

4.3 Peak Shaving Algorithm Given battery_kW and battery_kWh:

MaxReduction_kW = min(battery_kW, inverter_kW) MaxPossibleDuration = battery_kWh / MaxReduction_kW

If MaxPossibleDuration >= EventDuration: EffectiveReduction = MaxReduction_kW Else EffectiveReduction = battery_kWh / EventDuration

4.4 Annual Demand Savings Formula DemandSavings = EffectiveReduction × DemandCharge × 12

DemandCharge may have: Non-coincident component On-peak component Seasonal component

AI must always select the applicable demand charge for the peak period.

4.5 Edge Cases Case: Peak event lasts 3 hours; duration = 2 hours → AI must proportionally reduce savings

Case: Battery discharge capped at inverter → Use inverter_kW

Case: Two peaks of equal size → Only the highest month matters → But AI should warn if modeling uncertainty exists

Case: Negative battery savings due to DR reservation → AI must detect conflicts between DR and peak shaving

4.6 AI Guardrails Guardrail 1: Never produce “peak”, “part-peak”, and “off-peak” demand savings. Demand is one number. Guardrail 2: Never assume spike-shaving is sustainable. Guardrail 3: Always validate shaving duration. Guardrail 4: Document any assumptions imposed due to missing interval data.



SECTION 5 — ARBITRAGE ENGINE (EXTENDED)

5.1 Time-of-Use Arbitrage Prerequisites Arbitrage requires price spread > 0: Spread = PeakRate − OffPeakRate If Spread <= 0: ArbitrageSavings = 0

AI must not rely on part-peak arbitrage unless user explicitly requests it.

5.2 Charging Constraint Battery must recharge during off-peak window.

EnergyRequiredForNextDay = RawDailyDischarge ChargeCapacity = InverterLimit × OffPeakHours

If ChargeCapacity < EnergyRequired: DailyDischarge = ChargeCapacity × Efficiency

5.3 Daily Discharge Computation RawDailyDischarge = min(batt_kW × ArbitrageHours, batt_kWh)

DeliveredEnergy = RawDailyDischarge × RoundTripEfficiency

5.4 Annual Arbitrage AnnualDischarge_kWh = DeliveredEnergy × 365 AnnualArbitrageSavings = AnnualDischarge_kWh × Spread

5.5 Multi-Period Arbitrage AI should only use: Off-peak charge On-peak discharge

Part-peak should only be used if TOU structure requires it.

5.6 AI Guardrails Guardrail: Never triple-count arbitrage across peak, part-peak, off-peak. Guardrail: Arbitrage only occurs once per day unless user specifies multi-cycle mode. Guardrail: AI must check DR conflicts.

SECTION 6 — EXTENDED PHYSICS OF C-RATE, HEAT GENERATION, VOLTAGE SAG, AND RAMP PERFORMANCE

6.1 Internal Resistance and Voltage Sag When a battery discharges at high current, terminal voltage decreases due to internal resistance. Voltage = OpenCircuitVoltage − InternalResistance * Current

Because power equals voltage multiplied by current, high C-rates reduce effective AC output. AI must consider that real delivered kW may be lower than nameplate power when: C-rate exceeds 1 Battery is cold Battery is near maximum or minimum SOC Voltage derating is imposed

6.2 Thermal Rise from High C-Rate Heat generation is proportional to current squared multiplied by internal resistance: Heat = I^2 * R

High C-rate increases current linearly but increases heat quadratically. Batteries surpass thermal limits at high C-rates, triggering automatic derating. AI must model thermal derating when: Ambient temperature exceeds 35°C Battery cabinet is in poor ventilation Battery performs multiple cycles per day

6.3 Ramp Rate Requirements Some applications (demand response, grid services, UPS) require fast ramp. RampRate = dP/dt

Battery ramp rate limited by: Inverter current PCS firmware Grid code requirements Cell chemistry limitations

AI must not model DR participation if ramp rate < required program ramp rate.

6.4 SOC Window Requirements Batteries often operate only within a specific state of charge window. For example: Minimum SOC = 10% Maximum SOC = 90% Usable SOC window = 80% of nameplate energy

AI must always enforce SOC windows during charging and discharging.

6.5 C-Rate Impact on Efficiency At higher C-rates, round-trip efficiency decreases. Approximation used in modeling: Efficiency(C) = BaseEff − (C − 0.5)/10

Where BaseEff = 0.92 for LFP and 0.88 for NMC. AI must penalize arbitrage savings when discharge C-rate > 0.75.

6.6 Mathematical Validation Checks for AI Check 1: If C > 2, reject operation Check 2: If thermal_rise > OEM_max_temp, derate battery_kW Check 3: If voltage_sag causes inverter clipping, reduce AC_kW Check 4: If SOC_window < required discharge, reject event modeling

–––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––– SECTION 7 — DEGRADATION, LIFETIME MODELING, AND WARRANTY LOGIC (EXTENDED)

7.1 Two Types of Battery Degradation Calendar aging: time-based reduction in capacity Cycle aging: usage-based reduction in capacity

AI must track both.

7.2 Calendar Aging Model Annual calendar degradation typically ranges from 1.0% to 2.5% per year. DegradationCalendar = k_calendar * Years Where k_calendar ≈ 0.015 for LFP

7.3 Cycle Aging Model Cycle aging depends on depth of discharge (DoD). Common empirical relationship: DegradationCycle = k_cycle * (DoD)^α

α ranges from 1.2 to 1.4 depending on chemistry. k_cycle based on cycle count rating.

Example: If cell is rated for 6000 cycles at 80% DoD: k_cycle = 1 / 6000 AI must compute degraded capacity after n cycles.

7.4 Effective Battery Capacity Over Time EffectiveCapacity(year) = NominalCapacity * (1 − DegradationCalendar − DegradationCycle)

AI must use degraded capacity for annual savings, not initial capacity.

7.5 Warranty Enforcement Rules AI must reject scenarios where: CyclesPerYear > WarrantyCyclesPerYear C-rate > OEM maximum Average temperature > warranty temperature DoD exceeds warranty DoD limit

7.6 Battery Replacement Modeling For long-term NPV, the battery may need replacement after useful life. AI must incorporate mid-life replacement if analysis horizon > expected life.

7.7 Real-World Considerations Peak shaving uses fewer cycles than arbitrage; arbitrage-heavy models degrade faster. DR participation can cause deeper cycles, shortening life. AI must identify the dominant degradation mechanism for each use-case.

8.1 Types of DR Programs There are multiple forms of DR programs: Day-Ahead DR Real-Time DR Capacity Bidding Emergency Load Reduction Ancillary services DR Fast Frequency Response

AI must differentiate between them.

8.2 DR Requirements Breakdown Each DR program has: Event duration Event frequency per year Ramp rate requirements Notification time Sustained output requirements Reset/Recovery requirements For example: A DR program may require: Sustain 100 kW for 4 hours Up to 20 events per year 10-minute response time

Duration requirement: Battery_kWh / DR_committed_kW >= DR_event_duration

Recovery requirement: Available_offpeak_hours * ChargePower >= energy_depleted

AI must reject DR participation when any requirement is violated.

If goal = maximize bill savings: Prioritize demand shaving + arbitrage Allow DR only if non-conflicting

8.8 Fast Response DR Fast-acting DR requires: Ramp < 1 second C-rate > 2 In practice, most C&I batteries are not eligible AI must warn and automatically mark “Not Eligible”.

8.9 Real-World DR Mistakes AI Must Avoid Do not assume DR events last 15 minutes Do not assume arbitrary number of events Do not assume unlimited recharge capability Do not assume arbitrage is possible on same day as DR event Do not assume events occur in off-peak windows

SECTION 10 — EXTENDED FINANCIAL MODELING (NPV, IRR, PAYBACK, SGIP, CEFO, OBF)

10.1 Purpose of Financial Modeling The purpose of the financial model is to convert technical performance into economic outcomes. The financial model must translate battery dispatch into annual dollar savings, incentive value, capital cost, and long-term profitability metrics. The financial model provides decision-grade information for project scoping, proposal creation, and multi-measure optimization.

10.2 Core Financial Metrics The model calculates the following:

Annual demand savings Annual arbitrage savings Annual DR revenue Annual maintenance cost Annual net savings Simple payback Net present value (NPV) Internal rate of return (IRR) Levelized cost of energy storage (LCOS) CEFO or OBF loan eligibility SGIP incentive value

10.3 Capital Cost (CAPEX) CAPEX includes:

Battery modules Inverter and PCS Switchgear Transformer or service upgrades Installation labor Engineering Permitting Sales tax Commissioning Controls and EMS

The model must allow CAPEX to be reduced by incentives when rules permit.

10.4 Annual Operating Expenses (OPEX) Opex includes:

Annual maintenance contract EMS software licensing Warranty extension if required Insurance Performance testing Cyclical cost adjustments

AI must assume O&M cost is non-zero unless explicitly set to zero.

10.5 Annual Net Savings Annual net savings equal:

NetAnnualSavings = DemandSavings + ArbitrageSavings + DRRevenue − AnnualOandM

AI must prevent negative net savings unless intentionally modeling a poor asset.

10.6 Simple Payback Calculation SimplePayback = CAPEX / NetAnnualSavings AI must guard against:

Zero division errors NetAnnualSavings < 0 Reporting negative payback

10.7 Time Value of Money When calculating NPV, cashflow discounting must be applied:

NPV = −CAPEX + sum(NetAnnualSavings / (1 + discount_rate)^t)

AI must allow user-adjustable discount rates.

10.8 IRR Calculation IRR is the discount rate where NPV equals zero.

AI must not attempt symbolic derivation; instead use:

Newton-Raphson iterative approximation Bisection search Or internal function if provided

10.9 Lifecycle Replacement Modeling If analysis horizon exceeds battery life, replacement cost must be modeled:

ReplacementYear = expected_lifetime ReplacementCost = CAPEX * replacement_fraction DiscountedReplacementCost = ReplacementCost / (1 + discount_rate)^ReplacementYear

10.10 Salvage Value If battery life extends beyond analysis period, salvage value may be included:

SalvageValue = RemainingValue / (1 + discount_rate)^analysis_years AI must not overstate salvage value.

10.11 Fuel Adjustment Logic If the battery reduces gas heating demand (through HVAC controls interaction), therms savings must be included. AI must use proper rates for therms.

10.12 Multi-Tariff Adjustment If the battery changes the customer’s tariff (for example, qualifying for a lower demand charge), AI must calculate:

OldBill NewBill Savings = OldBill − NewBill

Tariff migration is one of the strongest value drivers.

Base incentive Equity resiliency adder Large storage step-downs Discharge cycling bonus

AI must calculate:

SGIPIncentive = kWh * incentive_rate Adjusted for:

Step number Equity eligibility Maximum cap rules Operating profile

CreditCheckPass SimplePayback <= program maximum MaxTerm <= program limit CAPEX < program cap

Loan payment formula:

Payment = CAPEX * (r / (1 − (1 + r)^(−TermMonths)))

If DR revenue > theoretical maximum → error If TWh-level savings appear → error If NPV extremely large → check inputs If arbitrage savings exceed cycle capability → adjust If battery cycles per year exceed warranty → warn or reject

If user goal = maximize ROI: 1 arbitrage 2 demand shaving 3 DR

If goal = maximize demand shaving: 1 demand shaving 2 arbitrage 3 DR

If goal = maximize DR revenue: 1 DR 2 peak shaving 3 arbitrage

These determine SOC reserve strategy.

Step 1: Check DR event Step 2: Check peak shaving requirements Step 3: Check arbitrage opportunity Step 4: Maintain SOC window

SECTION 12 — MATHEMATICAL DERIVATIONS FOR MODELING

12.1 Peak Shaving Derivation Given interval demand d(t), target peak T, battery discharge P_batt, duration D, and SOC:

If d(t) > T: P_shave(t) = min(P_batt, d(t) − T)

Cumulative energy needed for event: E_event = sum(P_shave(t) * Δt)

Battery must satisfy: E_event <= usable_energy

If not: Scale P_shave(t) downward uniformly.

12.2 Arbitrage Derivation Let price schedule be p(t), off_peak_price = p_low, peak_price = p_high.

Battery charges during t where price = p_low. Battery discharges during t where price = p_high.

Energy delivered: E_del = min(P_batt * H_high, usable_energy) * efficiency

Annual arbitrage savings: S_arbitrage = E_del * 365 * (p_high − p_low)

12.3 DR Derivation Event revenue: R = P_commit * H_event * N_events * rate_event

Eligibility requires: usable_energy >= P_commit * H_event recharge_feasible = (charge_hours * charge_power) >= (P_commit * H_event)

12.4 Optimization Problem Let V(battery) = NPV(battery)

User goal transforms into: Select battery b in library such that: b* = argmax V(b)

Subject to constraints: C_rate_limit duration_limit discount_rate loan eligibility incentive eligibility

This is a bounded discrete optimization problem.

12.5 Battery Lifetime Derivation If cycle degradation = f(DoD), then after n cycles: Capacity_n = Capacity_0 * (1 − sum(f(DoD_i))) − calendar_degradation

12.6 Efficiency as Function of C Efficiency(C) = η0 − α*(C − C_ref)^2 Where α determined empirically. AI must use η0 = base efficiency and C_ref = mid C-rate.

SECTION 16 — SAFETY AND THERMAL MODELING

16.1 Purpose of Safety Modeling Battery systems operate under chemical, electrical, and thermal constraints. Safety models are crucial for ensuring that the AI never suggests operating parameters that violate physical, chemical, manufacturer, or code limitations. Safety modeling protects against fire risk, thermal runaway, overcurrent conditions, and inverter overload.

16.2 Thermal Runaway Basics Thermal runaway is a condition where heat generation exceeds heat dissipation, causing exponential temperature rise. It is triggered by: Internal short circuits Overcharging Excessive discharge current Mechanical penetration Manufacturing defects Elevated ambient temperatures

AI must never propose operating conditions that risk thermal runaway. Batteries must stay within the temperature envelopes stated by the manufacturer.

16.3 Temperature Operating Ranges Typical LFP operating range: Discharge: −20C to +55C Charge: 0C to +55C Optimal performance: 15C to 35C

Charging below freezing causes lithium plating. Discharging above 55C accelerates degradation.

16.4 Thermal Derating Battery inverters and PCS systems derate power based on temperature. Derating usually begins around 35C and becomes severe above 45C. AI must reduce effective battery power when ambient temperatures exceed thresholds.

16.5 Cooling Requirements Forced air cooling or liquid cooling systems maintain cell temperature. If cooling capacity is insufficient, battery output is reduced. AI must check if cooling power is adequate for high C-rates.

16.6 Chemical Stability LFP batteries are more stable than NMC and less prone to fire propagation. AI must identify chemistry type if known and adjust risk factors accordingly.

16.7 Safety Certification Rules AI must assume all batteries must comply with: UL 9540 UL 9540A NFPA 855 IEEE 1547 Local jurisdiction fire code spacing and ventilation

Even in modeling, AI cannot ignore these constraints when suggesting equipment.

16.8 Heat Generation Model Heat = I^2 * R_internal Where I = current, R_internal = internal resistance.

13.2 Root Causes of Thermal Runaway Thermal runaway may originate from: Internal short circuits Mechanical penetration Manufacturing defect Lithium plating followed by dendrite formation Overtemperature Overvoltage Overcurrent External fire exposure Poor ventilation causing trapped heat Failure of cooling systems Localized thermal gradients

13.3 Exothermic Reaction Model Thermal runaway begins when the rate of heat generated internally exceeds the rate at which the cooling system can remove heat.

Advanced Mathematical Architectures for Stochastic Energy Storage Optimization: Bridging Differentiable Programming, Probabilistic Forecasting, and Risk-Sensitive Reinforcement Learning





1. Introduction: The Stochastic Control Challenge of Demand Charge Management



The modern electrical grid is undergoing a fundamental transformation characterized by the rapid integration of intermittent renewable energy sources (RES) and the electrification of large-scale loads such as electric vehicle fleets and industrial heat pumps. In this dynamic landscape, the optimization of Battery Energy Storage Systems (BESS) has transcended simple arbitrage strategies—buying low and selling high—to encompass complex ancillary services and, most critically, peak shaving.1 Peak shaving, the reduction of grid demand during intervals of maximum consumption, is driven economically by demand charges: tariffs where utility customers are billed not just for the volume of energy consumed (kWh) but for the maximum rate of consumption (kW) recorded over a billing period, typically a month.3

From a mathematical perspective, demand charge management represents a uniquely challenging stochastic control problem. Unlike energy arbitrage, which relies on additive cost functions over time, the demand charge introduces a non-additive, non-convex $\max(\cdot)$ operator over the entire decision horizon. The cost function $J$ is generally formulated as:

$$ J = \sum_{t=1}^{T} c_t^{energy} P_t^{grid} \Delta t + c^{demand} \max_{t \in {1, \dots, T}} (P_t^{grid}) $$

This structure implies that a single suboptimal decision at any timestep $t$—specifically, a failure to discharge the battery during the true peak—can irrevocably determine the cost for the entire month, rendering all other optimal decisions moot.3 Furthermore, this operator is non-differentiable in the classical sense, complicating the application of gradient-based optimization methods common in modern machine learning.

Compounding this structural difficulty is the stochastic nature of the inputs. The load $P_t^{load}$ is a non-stationary time series subject to human behavior, industrial schedules, and weather conditions. Traditional "Predict-then-Optimize" frameworks, which first forecast the load using Mean Squared Error (MSE) loss and then optimize the battery schedule, fail to capture the asymmetric risk profile of this problem.7 Under-predicting a peak is catastrophically expensive, while over-predicting incurs only minor efficiency losses. Therefore, a robust model requires a paradigm shift towards advanced mathematical architectures that can handle:

High-Dimensional Probabilistic Forecasting: Moving beyond point estimates to model full conditional distributions and long-range dependencies, utilizing architectures like the Informer with $O(L \log L)$ complexity.9

End-to-End Differentiable Optimization: Embedding the optimization problem itself as a layer within the neural network (e.g., CvxPyLayers), allowing gradients to backpropagate through the KKT conditions of the physical constraints.10

Distributional and Risk-Sensitive Reinforcement Learning (RL): Replacing expected-value maximization with the optimization of Conditional Value at Risk (CVaR) via Distributional RL methods like Quantile Regression DQN (QR-DQN), and addressing sparse rewards through rigorous Potential-Based Reward Shaping (PBRS).11

This report provides an exhaustive mathematical analysis of these architectures, detailing the derivations, theoretical justifications, and integrative mechanisms required to build a state-of-the-art peak shaving model.



2. Physics and Economics of the BESS Environment



To construct a high-fidelity machine learning model, one must first rigorously define the physical and economic environment governing the BESS. The mathematical formulation of the state transitions and cost surfaces defines the manifold on which the learning algorithms must operate.



2.1 Battery State Dynamics and Efficiency Models



The evolution of the battery's energy state, $E_t$, is a discrete-time dynamical system. While simplified models assume constant efficiency, a high-performance model must account for the non-linear losses associated with electrochemical conversion.

Let $P_t^{batt}$ be the power flow at the battery terminals at time $t$, where $P_t^{batt} > 0$ denotes discharging (injecting power to the building/grid) and $P_t^{batt} < 0$ denotes charging. The net power drawn from the grid, $P_t^{grid}$, is given by the power balance equation:





$$P_t^{grid} = P_t^{load} - P_t^{batt}$$



Ideally, we constrain $P_t^{grid} \le P_{limit}$, but in the demand charge context, $P_{limit}$ is a decision variable (the target peak) rather than a hard physical constraint.3

The state of charge (SoC) update equation incorporates charging efficiency $\eta_{ch} \in (0, 1]$ and discharging efficiency $\eta_{dis} \in (0, 1]$:

$$ E_{t+1} = E_t - \left( \frac{1}{\eta_{dis}} \cdot [P_t^{batt}]^+ - \eta_{ch} \cdot [P_t^{batt}]^- \right) \Delta t $$

where $[x]^+ = \max(0, x)$ and $[x]^- = \max(0, -x)$.

This piecewise linear formulation introduces a non-smoothness at $P_t^{batt} = 0$. In convex optimization contexts, this is typically handled by splitting $P_t^{batt}$ into two non-negative variables, $P_t^{dis}$ and $P_t^{ch}$, such that $P_t^{batt} = P_t^{dis} - P_t^{ch}$. To prevent simultaneous charging and discharging (which is physically impossible but mathematically feasible in relaxed linear programs), one often introduces binary variables or relies on the cost structure to discourage waste. However, in a differentiable layer context, avoiding binary variables is crucial to maintain gradient flow.14 The objective function naturally penalizes simultaneous flows because $\eta_{ch} < 1$ and $\eta_{dis} < 1$ imply that any circular flow dissipates energy, increasing the net cost.

Physical constraints define the feasible region $\mathcal{C}$:





$$E_{min} \le E_t \le E_{max} \quad \forall t$$



$$0 \le P_t^{ch} \le P_{max}^{ch}$$



$$0 \le P_t^{dis} \le P_{max}^{dis}$$



2.2 The Non-Convexity of Demand Tariffs



The economic landscape is defined by the tariff structure. Industrial tariffs typically include:

Time-of-Use (ToU) Energy Charges: $c_t^{energy}$ varies by hour (e.g., on-peak, off-peak, super-off-peak).

Demand Charges: A high cost $c^{demand}$ applied to the maximum grid power drawn over the billing cycle $T$.

The demand charge term, $C_{DC} = c^{demand} \max_{t \in} P_t^{grid}$, creates a global dependency. The gradient of this term with respect to power at time $t$, $\frac{\partial C_{DC}}{\partial P_t^{grid}}$, is zero for all $t$ except the set of timesteps where the maximum is achieved.

$$ \frac{\partial C_{DC}}{\partial P_t^{grid}} = \begin{cases} c^{demand} & \text{if } P_t^{grid} = \max_{\tau} P_\tau^{grid} \ 0 & \text{otherwise} \end{cases} $$

This "sparse gradient" problem makes direct gradient descent training difficult. If the model successfully lowers the current peak at $t_{peak}$, the gradient instantly shifts to a new $t'_{peak}$. This phenomenon, known as "peak hopping," requires the optimization landscape to consider the joint distribution of all potential peaks, not just the current maximum.3

Furthermore, the billing period $T$ (one month) is significantly longer than the typical prediction horizon of standard load forecasters (24-48 hours). This necessitates a hierarchical or "rolling horizon" approach where short-term decisions are guided by long-term value functions or cost-to-go approximations derived from RL or advanced forecasting.16



3. Advanced Probabilistic Forecasting: The Informer Architecture



To mitigate the risk of peak exceedance, the control model requires accurate probabilistic forecasts of future loads. Standard Recurrent Neural Networks (RNNs) or LSTMs struggle with the long sequences required to capture weekly or monthly periodicities ($L \approx 720$ to $2000$ hourly steps). The Transformer architecture, while powerful in capturing long-range dependencies via self-attention, suffers from $O(L^2)$ computational and memory complexity. For peak shaving, where we must analyze weeks of history to predict extreme events, this quadratic scaling is prohibitive.

The Informer architecture 9 solves this via the ProbSparse Self-Attention mechanism, achieving $O(L \log L)$ complexity. We will now rigorously derive the mathematics behind this efficiency and its relevance to building the peak shaving model.



3.1 Mathematical Derivation of ProbSparse Attention



The standard self-attention mechanism computes a score between a query $Q$, key $K$, and value $V$:





$$\text{Attention}(Q, K, V) = \text{Softmax}\left(\frac{QK^T}{\sqrt{d}}\right)V$$



Let $q_i$ be the $i$-th row of $Q$, $k_j$ the $j$-th row of $K$, and $v_j$ the $j$-th row of $V$. The attention weight $A(q_i, K)$ defines a probability distribution $p(k_j | q_i)$ over the keys:





$$p(k_j | q_i) = \frac{\exp(q_i k_j^T / \sqrt{d})}{\sum_{l} \exp(q_i k_l^T / \sqrt{d})}$$

The Sparsity Hypothesis:

Empirical observation in time-series data suggests that the distribution of attention scores is long-tailed. For many queries, the dot products $q_i k_j^T$ result in a near-uniform probability distribution over keys. A uniform attention distribution, $q(k_j | q_i) = 1/L_K$, essentially computes a mean of the value vectors $V$, providing no specific local information. These are termed "lazy" queries. Conversely, "active" queries have a sharp, peaked distribution, focusing heavily on specific keys (e.g., historical peak events similar to the current context).19

To optimize efficiency, we should only compute the expensive dot products for "active" queries. We identify these by measuring the Kullback-Leibler (KL) Divergence between the query's attention distribution $p$ and the uniform distribution $q$:

$$ KL(q_i |

| U) = \sum_{j=1}^{L_K} p(k_j | q_i) \ln \frac{p(k_j | q_i)}{1/L_K} $$

$$ KL(q_i |

| U) = \ln L_K + \sum_{j=1}^{L_K} p(k_j | q_i) \ln p(k_j | q_i) $$

Since explicitly computing $p(k_j | q_i)$ requires the $O(L)$ summation we wish to avoid, the Informer uses an approximation based on the Log-Sum-Exp (LSE) inequality. The sparsity measurement $M(q_i, K)$ is defined as:

$$ M(q_i, K) = \ln \sum_{j=1}^{L_K} \exp\left(\frac{q_i k_j^T}{\sqrt{d}}\right) - \frac{1}{L_K} \sum_{j=1}^{L_K} \frac{q_i k_j^T}{\sqrt{d}} $$

This measurement represents the difference between the LSE of the unnormalized attention scores and their arithmetic mean.21 If this difference is large, the distribution is peaked (active). If small, it is uniform (lazy).

Sampling Approximation:

To avoid iterating over all $j$, the Informer randomly samples a subset of keys $U_{sample}$ of size $c \cdot \ln L_K$. The measurement is approximated as:

$$ \bar{M}(q_i, K) = \max_{k_j \in U_{sample}} \left(\frac{q_i k_j^T}{\sqrt{d}}\right) - \frac{1}{L_K} \sum_{k_j \in U_{sample}} \left(\frac{q_i k_j^T}{\sqrt{d}}\right) $$

Using this metric, we select the top-$u$ queries (where $u = c \cdot \ln L_Q$). We compute the full cross-attention only for these $u$ queries. For the remaining $L_Q - u$ queries, we simply assign the mean of the value vectors $V$. This reduces the complexity from $O(L^2)$ to $O(L \log L)$, allowing the model to process significantly longer history windows (e.g., 2 weeks at 15-minute resolution = 1344 points) to identify recurring peak patterns.9



3.2 Self-Attention Distilling and Generative Decoding



For peak shaving, we need to predict a sequence of future loads (e.g., the next 24 hours). The Informer employs a Generative Style Decoder to output the entire sequence in a single forward pass, unlike the step-by-step autoregressive decoding of standard Transformers which accumulates error.

Furthermore, to handle the hierarchy of temporal features (from weekly trends down to hourly spikes), the encoder uses Self-Attention Distilling. Between attention blocks, a convolutional layer with max-pooling reduces the sequence length:





$$X_{j+1} = \text{MaxPool}(\text{ELU}(\text{Conv1d}(X_j)))$$



This operation halves the dimension $L$ at each layer, constructing a pyramid of features. Mathematically, this enforces that higher layers in the network attend to coarser-grained, dominant features (like daily baselines), while lower layers attend to fine-grained details (like instantaneous power spikes). This multi-scale representation is critical for separating the "base load" from the "peak load" components of the demand.19



3.3 Pinball Loss for Probabilistic Output



Standard regression minimizes Mean Squared Error (MSE), which estimates the conditional mean $\mathbb{E}[y|x]$. However, for risk-sensitive control, we need the conditional quantiles (e.g., the 90th percentile $q_{0.9}$). We employ the Pinball Loss (or Quantile Loss).24

For a quantile $\tau \in (0, 1)$, the loss is:





$$L_\tau(y, \hat{y}) = \max(\tau(y - \hat{y}), (\tau - 1)(y - \hat{y}))$$

Gradient Analysis:

The gradient of the Pinball loss with respect to the prediction $\hat{y}$ is:

$$ \frac{\partial L_\tau}{\partial \hat{y}} = \begin{cases} -\tau & \text{if } y > \hat{y} \ 1 - \tau & \text{if } y \le \hat{y} \end{cases} $$

This gradient is constant but asymmetric. If $\tau = 0.95$ (modeling the upper tail of demand), under-prediction ($y > \hat{y}$) generates a gradient of magnitude $0.95$, while over-prediction generates a gradient of $0.05$. This forces the neural network to prioritize upper-bound accuracy heavily. By training on a composite loss $\mathcal{L} = \sum_{\tau \in \mathcal{T}} L_\tau$, where $\mathcal{T} = \{0.1, 0.5, 0.9\}$, the Informer outputs a full probabilistic cone of future demand, enabling the optimization layer to make risk-aware decisions.26



4. End-to-End Differentiable Optimization Layers



The classical "Predict-then-Optimize" pipeline decouples the forecasting model from the decision model. The forecaster minimizes Pinball loss, and the optimizer minimizes cost given the forecast. This is suboptimal because the "cost of error" is not uniform; an error in forecasting a non-peak hour has zero economic impact, while an error at a peak hour has massive impact.

To align these objectives, we utilize Differentiable Convex Optimization Layers (such as CvxPyLayers or OptNet). This allows us to embed the battery dispatch optimization inside the neural network, permitting backpropagation from the final electricity bill directly to the forecasting weights.10



4.1 Canonicalization and the KKT Conditions



We formulate the daily battery dispatch as a convex optimization problem parameterized by the forecast $\hat{y}$ (output of the Informer). Let $z$ be the decision variables (battery power $P^{batt}$, state of energy $E$).



$$\min_z f(z; \theta) \quad \text{s.t. } Gz \le h, Az = b$$

Here, $\theta$ represents the parameters provided by the neural network (e.g., the forecasted load vector $\hat{P}^{load}$). The layer outputs the optimal schedule $z^*(\theta)$.

To compute the gradient $\frac{\partial \mathcal{L}}{\partial \theta}$ (where $\mathcal{L}$ is the final cost), we need the Jacobian $\frac{\partial z^*}{\partial \theta}$. We derive this by differentiating the Karush-Kuhn-Tucker (KKT) optimality conditions.

The KKT conditions for the problem are:

Primal Feasibility: $Az^* - b = 0, \quad Gz^* - h \le 0$

Dual Feasibility: $\lambda^* \ge 0$

Stationarity: $\nabla_z f(z^*) + A^T \nu^* + G^T \lambda^* = 0$

Complementary Slackness: $\text{diag}(\lambda^*) (Gz^* - h) = 0$

Let $\mathcal{R}(z, \lambda, \nu, \theta) = 0$ be the system of equations representing these conditions. By the Implicit Function Theorem, the total differential is zero:

$$ \nabla_\theta \mathcal{R} + \nabla_{(z, \lambda, \nu)} \mathcal{R} \cdot \frac{\partial (z, \lambda, \nu)}{\partial \theta} = 0 $$

Thus, the Jacobian of the solution is:

$$ \frac{\partial (z^, \lambda^, \nu^*)}{\partial \theta} = - \left( \nabla_{(z, \lambda, \nu)} \mathcal{R} \right)^{-1} \nabla_\theta \mathcal{R} $$

The matrix $\nabla_{(z, \lambda, \nu)} \mathcal{R}$ is the KKT matrix. For a quadratic program (QP), this matrix takes the form:





$$K = \begin{bmatrix} Q & G^T & A^T \\ D(\lambda^*)G & D(Gz^* - h) & 0 \\ A & 0 & 0 \end{bmatrix}$$



where $D(\cdot)$ denotes a diagonal matrix.



4.2 Handling Active Constraints and Matrix Singularity



In battery optimization, constraints such as $E_{min} \le E_t \le E_{max}$ are frequently active (the battery is full or empty). The complementary slackness condition introduces non-differentiability when a constraint switches from active to inactive. CvxPyLayers handles this by smoothing the KKT conditions or by formulating the backward pass using the homogeneous self-dual embedding.10

A critical implementation detail is ensuring the KKT matrix $K$ is non-singular. In cases where the problem is degenerate (e.g., multiple optimal solutions), $K$ is not invertible. To mitigate this, we add a small regularization term $\epsilon \|z\|_2^2$ to the objective function, making the problem strictly convex and the KKT matrix non-singular. This ensures stable gradient flow even when the battery is idle.29



4.3 Integrating with the Peak Shaving Loss



With the Jacobian $\frac{\partial z^*}{\partial \hat{y}}$ available, we define the loss function as the actual cost of the schedule $z^*$ against the true load $y_{true}$:





$$\mathcal{L}(\theta) = \text{Cost}(z^*(\hat{y}(\theta)), y_{true})$$



$$ \nabla_\theta \mathcal{L} = \frac{\partial \text{Cost}}{\partial z^} \cdot \frac{\partial z^}{\partial \hat{y}} \cdot \frac{\partial \hat{y}}{\partial \theta} $$

This gradient chain has a profound physical interpretation. The term $\frac{\partial z^*}{\partial \hat{y}}$ quantifies the sensitivity of the battery schedule to the forecast.

If the battery is constrained (e.g., fully charged) and cannot react to a change in forecast, the sensitivity is zero, and the gradient vanishes.

If the battery is actively shaving a peak, the sensitivity is high.

Critically, this mechanism automatically weights the forecasting loss. Errors in the forecast that do not change the optimal dispatch (e.g., errors during off-peak times where the battery is idle) receive zero weight. Errors during peak times that alter the dispatch receive high weight. This effectively learns a "task-based loss function" without manual engineering.7



5. Distributional Reinforcement Learning



While differentiable optimization is powerful for planning over short, deterministic horizons, it struggles with the inherent stochasticity of the month-long demand charge problem. The "true" peak might occur 20 days from now, beyond the horizon of a daily optimizer. Reinforcement Learning (RL) maps states to actions $(s \to a)$ to maximize long-term cumulative reward, making it suitable for this infinite-horizon control.

However, standard RL (like DQN or PPO) estimates the expected return $Q(s,a) = \mathbb{E}$. For peak shaving, the expected return is insufficient because the cost is driven by tail risks (rare, extreme load events). A policy that maximizes expected return might be risky, accepting a 5% chance of a massive peak to save small amounts of energy daily. We need a risk-averse policy, which requires Distributional RL.11



5.1 The Distributional Bellman Operator



In Distributional RL, we model the full distribution of returns $Z(s,a)$ rather than just its mean. The scalar Bellman equation is replaced by a distributional one:





$$Z(s,a) \overset{D}{=} R(s,a) + \gamma Z(s', a')$$



where $\overset{D}{=}$ denotes equality in distribution. $Z$ is a random variable.

To implement this, we use Quantile Regression DQN (QR-DQN).33 We approximate the distribution $Z(s,a)$ using a discrete set of $N$ quantiles, supported at cumulative probabilities $\tau_i = \frac{i - 0.5}{N}$ for $i=1, \dots, N$. The network outputs a vector $\boldsymbol{\theta}(s,a) \in \mathbb{R}^N$, where $\theta_i$ estimates the value of the $\tau_i$-th quantile.



5.2 Wasserstein Distance and Quantile Loss



Unlike Categorical DQN (C51) which minimizes KL divergence between categorical distributions, QR-DQN minimizes the 1-Wasserstein distance between the predicted distribution and the target distribution. The Wasserstein metric is crucial here because it is a true metric on probability distributions and provides meaningful gradients even when the supports of the distributions are disjoint (which is common in deterministic reward environments like battery control).35

The loss function for QR-DQN is the Huber Quantile Loss averaged over all pairs of predicted quantiles $\theta_i$ and target quantiles $\theta_j'$:

$$ \mathcal{L}{QR} = \sum{i=1}^N \mathbb{E}{s,a,r,s'} \left[ \sum{j=1}^N \rho_{\tau_i}^\kappa (r + \gamma \theta_j(s', a^*) - \theta_i(s,a)) \right]

$$where $\rho_{\tau}^\kappa(u)$ is the Huber loss variants for quantiles:$$

\rho_{\tau}^\kappa(u) = | \tau - \mathbb{I}{{u < 0}} | \frac{\mathcal{L}\kappa(u)}{\kappa} $$

and $\mathcal{L}_\kappa$ is the standard Huber loss.



5.3 Implicit Quantile Networks (IQN)



An advancement over QR-DQN is Implicit Quantile Networks (IQN). Instead of fixed quantiles $\tau_i$, IQN takes $\tau$ as an input to the network (sampled from a base distribution, e.g., $U$) and outputs the corresponding quantile value $Z_\tau(s,a)$.





$$Z_\tau(s,a) \approx f(\psi(s), \phi(\tau))$$



where $\phi(\tau)$ is an embedding of the probability $\tau$. This allows the network to query any part of the return distribution distribution, providing infinite resolution. For peak shaving, this is valuable as it allows us to focus arbitrarily closely on the extreme tails ($\tau \to 1$) where the demand charge risks lie.12



6. Risk-Sensitive Control via CVaR Optimization



Having access to the return distribution $Z(s,a)$ enables us to construct policies that explicitly minimize tail risk. The most appropriate risk measure for peak shaving is Conditional Value at Risk (CVaR) (also known as Expected Shortfall).



6.1 CVaR Formulation



For a random cost variable $C$ (or negative return $-Z$) and confidence level $\alpha \in (0,1)$ (e.g., $\alpha=0.05$), the Value at Risk ($VaR_\alpha$) is:





$$VaR_\alpha(C) = \inf \{ c : P(C \le c) \ge \alpha \}$$



The $CVaR_\alpha$ is the expected cost given that the cost exceeds the VaR:





$$CVaR_\alpha(C) = \mathbb{E}$$

In the context of Distributional RL, where $Z$ represents returns (higher is better), we are interested in the lower tail (worst outcomes). The lower-tail CVaR at level $\alpha$ is:





$$CVaR_\alpha(Z) = \mathbb{E}[Z | Z \le F_Z^{-1}(\alpha)]$$



6.2 Risk-Sensitive Policy Update



With QR-DQN, we have explicit estimates of the quantiles $\theta_1, \dots, \theta_N$. Since $\tau_i$ are uniformly spaced, the $\alpha$-CVaR can be approximated by averaging the lowest $k = \lfloor \alpha N \rfloor$ quantiles.34

The risk-sensitive policy $\pi_{CVaR}$ selects actions to maximize this lower-tail average, effectively ignoring the optimistic upper tail:





$$a^*_{CVaR} = \text{argmax}_{a \in \mathcal{A}} \sum_{i=1}^{\lfloor \alpha N \rfloor} \theta_i(s,a)$$

This mathematical modification transforms the agent. A standard agent ($\alpha=1$) maximizes the mean. A risk-averse agent ($\alpha=0.1$) maximizes the worst-case 10% of outcomes.

Insight: In peak shaving, this means the agent will discharge the battery even if the probability of a peak is only 10%. It hedges against the "worst-case scenario" that the load might spike, ensuring the demand charge is minimized even in unlikely weather events. This robustness is mathematically guaranteed by the CVaR objective.37



6.3 Policy Gradient Theorem for CVaR



For continuous control (where action space is continuous power $P^{batt}$), we cannot simply iterate over discrete actions. We must use policy gradient methods. The gradient of the CVaR objective requires careful derivation.

Using the dual representation of CVaR:





$$CVaR_\alpha(Z) = \max_{\nu} \left( \nu - \frac{1}{\alpha} \mathbb{E}[( \nu - Z )^+] \right)$$

Tamar et al. 39 derived the gradient of CVaR with respect to policy parameters $\theta$:



$$\nabla_\theta J_{CVaR}(\theta) = \frac{1}{\alpha} \mathbb{E}_{s,a \sim \pi_\theta} \left$$



where $\nu^*$ is the optimal VaR value.

Interpretation: The indicator function $\mathbb{I}_{\{R \le \nu^*\}}$ acts as a filter. The gradient is computed only using trajectories that resulted in returns worse than the VaR threshold. This focuses the learning entirely on the "failure cases" (months where peaks were not successfully shaved), ensuring the neural network updates its weights to specifically prevent these catastrophic outliers. This is mathematically distinct from standard Policy Gradient (REINFORCE), which averages over all trajectories.41



7. Addressing Sparse Rewards: Potential-Based Reward Shaping



A fundamental difficulty in RL for demand charges is the reward sparsity. The agent receives feedback on the demand charge only at the end of the month (step $T \approx 720$). For the preceding 719 steps, the demand charge reward is zero. This "temporal credit assignment" problem makes convergence usually slow or impossible.42

To solve this, we employ Potential-Based Reward Shaping (PBRS). We construct a shaping function $F(s,s')$ that provides immediate feedback while mathematically guaranteeing that the optimal policy is unchanged.



7.1 PBRS Theorem and Policy Invariance



According to Ng et al. 43, if the shaping reward is of the form:





$$F(s, s') = \gamma \Phi(s') - \Phi(s)$$



where $\Phi: S \to \mathbb{R}$ is any real-valued function of state, then the optimal policy $\pi^*$ for the shaped MDP is identical to the optimal policy for the original MDP. This is a rigorous sufficiency condition.



7.2 Deriving the Demand Charge Potential



We need a potential function $\Phi(s)$ that captures the "loom" of the demand charge. Let the state $s_t$ include the variable $p_t^{max}$, representing the maximum peak recorded so far in the current billing cycle:





$$p_t^{max} = \max(P_1^{grid}, \dots, P_t^{grid})$$

The final demand charge cost is $C_{DC} = \mu_d \cdot p_T^{max}$. This suggests the potential function should be related to the negative of the current accumulated peak cost:





$$\Phi(s_t) = - \mu_d \cdot p_t^{max}$$

Substituting this into the PBRS equation:





$$F(s_t, s_{t+1}) = \gamma (-\mu_d p_{t+1}^{max}) - (-\mu_d p_t^{max})$$



$$F(s_t, s_{t+1}) = \mu_d (p_t^{max} - \gamma p_{t+1}^{max})$$

Assuming $\gamma \approx 1$ for the shaping intuition:





$$F(s_t, s_{t+1}) \approx -\mu_d (p_{t+1}^{max} - p_t^{max})$$

Mathematical Implication:

If $P_{t+1}^{grid} \le p_t^{max}$, then $p_{t+1}^{max} = p_t^{max}$, and $F \approx 0$.

If $P_{t+1}^{grid} > p_t^{max}$, then $p_{t+1}^{max} > p_t^{max}$, and $F < 0$. Specifically, $F = -\mu_d (P_{t+1}^{grid} - p_t^{max})$.

This transformation converts the sparse monthly penalty into a dense, immediate penalty. Every time the agent allows the grid power to exceed the current month's historical maximum, it receives an instantaneous penalty proportional to the increment of the new peak. This provides a dense gradient signal at every step where a new peak is established, allowing the value function to converge rapidly while mathematically preserving the global optimality of the monthly minimization objective.6



8. Integrated Architecture: The End-to-End Relearning Framework



To synthesize these components into a unified model, we propose a Bi-Level End-to-End Relearning Framework.46



8.1 Architecture Diagram



Outer Loop (Policy Learning): A Risk-Sensitive Distributional RL agent (QR-DQN) determines the high-level strategy (e.g., target SoC or marginal price threshold) to manage long-term risk and monthly demand charges.

Inner Loop (Differentiable Control): A CvxPyLayer solves the short-term (24h) constrained optimization problem given the RL agent's strategic parameters and the Informer's probabilistic forecasts.

Forecaster: The Informer network provides quantile forecasts $\hat{Y} = [\hat{y}_{0.1}, \hat{y}_{0.5}, \hat{y}_{0.9}]$.

Data Flow:

$$ \text{State } s_t \xrightarrow{Informer} \hat{Y}_t \xrightarrow{QR-DQN} \text{Strategy } \theta_t \xrightarrow{CvxPyLayer} \text{Action } P_t^{batt} $$



8.2 Joint Optimization Objective



The entire pipeline is differentiable. We can define a joint loss function:

$$ \mathcal{L}{total} = \lambda_1 \mathcal{L}{Pinball}(\hat{Y}, Y_{true}) + \lambda_2 \mathcal{L}{CVaR}(P^{batt}, C{DC}) + \lambda_3 \mathcal{L}_{Reg} $$

Gradients backpropagate from the CVaR cost through the CvxPyLayer (via KKT implicit differentiation) to the QR-DQN and Informer weights simultaneously. This ensures that the forecaster learns features relevant to control (features that minimize CVaR) rather than just minimizing RMSE.46



8.3 Handling Non-Stationarity



Grid environments are non-stationary (NS-MDP). Seasonality and degrading battery health change the transition dynamics $P(s'|s,a)$. The framework includes a Relearning Trigger. We monitor the distribution of prediction errors. If the KL divergence between the recent error distribution and the training error distribution exceeds a threshold $\delta$, the model triggers an online update, fine-tuning the weights on the most recent window of experience. This ensures the model adapts to seasonal shifts or battery aging effects.46



9. Conclusion



The optimization of energy storage for peak shaving is a problem that defies simple heuristic or standard supervised learning solutions due to the specific mathematical properties of the demand charge: global temporal dependency, non-convexity of the max operator, and the extreme asymmetry of risk.

To build a robust model, one must implement a stack of advanced mathematical architectures:

Forecasting: Informer with ProbSparse Attention ($O(L \log L)$) and Pinball Loss to capture the conditional distribution of long-sequence load data.

Optimization: Differentiable Convex Layers (CvxPyLayers) to allow end-to-end gradient flow through the physical constraints of the battery.

Control: Distributional RL (QR-DQN) to model the full return distribution and optimize CVaR, ensuring robustness against tail risks.

Reward Shaping: Potential-Based Reward Shaping with the potential $\Phi(s) = -\mu p_{max}$ to rigorously solve the sparse reward problem while maintaining policy invariance.

This integrated approach moves beyond "black-box" AI, leveraging domain-specific mathematical structures to solve the unique challenges of the stochastic energy grid.

Optimal Control Architectures for Battery-Based Peak Demand Management: A Comprehensive Technical Report





Executive Summary



The transition of energy storage systems (BESS) from passive assets to active, intelligent grid resources necessitates a fundamental shift in control logic. The specific operational failure identified—an AI model that discharges continuously ("shaves all day") rather than targeting specific high-value intervals—indicates a misalignment between the control algorithm’s objective function and the stochastic, scarcity-driven nature of peak demand management. In the domain of commercial and industrial (C&I) energy management, energy (kWh) is a finite resource that must be surgically deployed to reduce power capacity (kW). A strategy that flattens "broad hills" of load rather than "needle peaks" dissipates stored energy on intervals that carry zero marginal economic value, rendering the system incapable of mitigating the true monthly maximum demand.

This report provides an exhaustive technical analysis of the data architectures, mathematical formulations, and control strategies required to rectify this failure. It moves beyond simple heuristic thresholding to explore rigorous optimization frameworks—specifically Mixed-Integer Linear Programming (MILP) for deterministic planning and Reinforcement Learning (RL) for stochastic control. By integrating specific input datasets (electricity rates, battery physics, interval load data), we define a "Peak-Aware" state space that enables the AI to quantify the opportunity cost of every discharged kilowatt-hour. The analysis demonstrates that effective peak shaving requires a system that learns to value the preservation of energy as highly as its deployment, acting only when the probability of setting a new billing peak exceeds a dynamically calculated risk threshold.



1. The Physics and Economics of Peak Shaving



To engineer an AI capable of effective Demand Charge Management (DCM), one must first define the boundary conditions of the problem: the economic signals sent by the utility and the physical constraints imposed by the battery. The observed failure mode of continuous discharge suggests a fundamental misunderstanding of these boundary conditions within the current model's logic.



1.1 The Economic Objective: Capacity vs. Energy



The primary error in the current application is likely the conflation of energy arbitrage with demand charge management.

Energy Arbitrage creates value by exploiting the differential in energy prices ($\$/kWh$) over time. Since prices often follow a diurnal curve (low at night, high during the day), an arbitrage-focused algorithm will discharge continuously throughout the on-peak window.1

Peak Shaving creates value by reducing the maximum instantaneous power draw ($\$/kW$) recorded over a billing cycle. This charge is typically determined by a single 15-minute or 30-minute interval.3

Because the demand charge is determined by the single highest interval, reducing load in any other interval has zero marginal value for the capacity component of the bill. If a facility’s load profile has a "needle peak" of 500 kW at 2:00 PM and a "broad hill" of 400 kW from 9:00 AM to 5:00 PM, discharging at 10:00 AM reduces energy costs (arbitrage) but contributes nothing to demand reduction if the 2:00 PM peak is not also addressed. "Shaving all day" implies the AI is optimizing for energy volume rather than peak magnitude.



1.2 The "Needle Peak" vs. "Broad Hill" Topology



The shape of the customer's load profile dictates the requisite energy-to-power ratio (E/P ratio) of the BESS and the difficulty of the control problem.

Needle Peaks: Characterized by low load factors, these peaks are sharp and short-duration. A BESS can effectively shave these with minimal energy expenditure. This is the ideal scenario for high-ROI peak shaving.4

Broad Hills: Characterized by high load factors (e.g., continuous industrial processes). Shaving these requires massive energy reserves. If the AI attempts to shave a broad hill with a battery sized for needle peaks, it will hit its minimum State of Charge (SoC) long before the high-load period ends. Once the battery is empty, the load returns to the grid level, setting a peak that negates all previous shaving efforts.5

The AI must effectively perform Load Duration Curve Analysis in real-time. It must integrate the area under the curve above a candidate threshold $P_{target}$ to determine if the battery's energy capacity $E_{batt}$ is sufficient to sustain that threshold for the entire duration of the violation.



$$E_{required} = \int_{t_{start}}^{t_{end}} \max(0, P_{load}(t) - P_{target}) \, dt$$

The condition for feasibility is $E_{required} \leq E_{batt} \cdot \eta_{discharge}$. The current AI model likely lacks this integral check, leading it to attack a target it cannot sustain.6



1.3 Rate Structures as Design Constraints



The "library of electricity rates" mentioned in the query contains the essential constraints for the optimization problem. These must be parsed into specific feature vectors for the AI.

Data Structure

Impact on Control Logic

Consumption Charge

Time-Series Vector ($/kWh)

Incentivizes arbitrage. Can conflict with peak shaving if high prices don't align with peaks.

Demand Charge (NCP)

Scalar ($/kW)

The primary driver for "Peak-So-Far" logic. Drives the scarcity value of energy.

Ratchet Clause

Constraint ($P_{min}$)

A billing mechanism where the billable peak is the maximum of the current month OR a percentage of the annual peak (e.g., 80% of summer max).3 This sets a hard floor; shaving below this level yields zero savings.

Stochastic Flag

A charge based on the grid's peak, not the customer's. Requires external grid forecasting features.

The "Shaving All Day" error often arises when the optimizer over-weights the Consumption Charge (Arbitrage) relative to the Demand Charge, or fails to model the Ratchet Clause, attempting to shave below a "sunk cost" floor.



2. Advanced Data Engineering: Feeding the AI



The user query specifies that the system has access to "customer interval data," "batteries," and "electricity rates." To fix the control logic, these raw inputs must be transformed into a sophisticated State Space that gives the AI situational awareness. The model cannot learn to conserve energy for a future peak if its input features do not explicitly quantify "risk" and "future scarcity."



2.1 The "Peak-Aware" State Space Features



Standard time-series forecasting uses past load to predict future load. For peak shaving, the AI needs features that describe the relationship between the current load and the billing constraints. The following engineered features are mandatory.7



2.1.1 The "Peak-So-Far" Vector



This is the single most critical feature for preventing unnecessary discharge.

Peak_Observed_Month ($P_{max\_observed}$): The maximum demand recorded by the meter since the start of the current billing cycle.

Calculation: $P_{max\_observed} = \max(\{P_{load}(\tau) \mid \tau \in [0, t]\})$

Headroom ($P_{headroom}$): The distance between the current load and the observed peak.

Calculation: $P_{headroom}(t) = P_{load}(t) - P_{max\_observed}$

Signal Value:

If $P_{headroom} > 0$: The facility is actively setting a new peak. The battery must discharge to defend the threshold.

If $P_{headroom} < 0$: The current load is below the peak. Discharge provides no demand charge savings. The AI should idle or charge, unless energy arbitrage ($/kWh) is extremely profitable.

Insight: In the current failing model, this feature is likely missing or ignored, causing the agent to see "high load" as a trigger to discharge, even if that "high load" is 50 kW below the peak set yesterday.



2.1.2 Temporal Scarcity Features



Billing_Cycle_Progress: A normalized scalar ($0 \rightarrow 1$) indicating position in the billing month.

Relevance: Early in the month, setting a new peak is low-risk (there are 29 days left to set a higher one). Late in the month, setting a new peak is catastrophic (it locks in the charge). The AI should learn to be risk-neutral early and risk-averse late.8

Days_Remaining: Integer count of days left. Used to calculate the "option value" of stored energy.



2.1.3 Cyclical Time Encoding



Raw timestamps (e.g., hour 0-23) introduce discontinuities. Cyclical encoding preserves temporal proximity.10

Hour_Sin / Hour_Cos: $\sin(2\pi h/24)$, $\cos(2\pi h/24)$.

Month_Sin / Month_Cos: Captures seasonal variations in HVAC load (cooling degree days).



2.2 Battery State and Physics Features



The "batteries with their sizing and cost" data must be converted into dynamic state variables.

SoC (State of Charge): Current energy level (normalized $0 \rightarrow 1$).

SoH (State of Health): A derating factor (e.g., 0.92) representing capacity fade. The AI must know that 100% SoC today represents fewer kWh than it did last year.11

C_Rate_Limit: The maximum power the battery can inject at this specific moment. This is non-linear; as SoC drops below 10-20% or temperature drops, the BMS (Battery Management System) throttles power output. If the AI expects 100kW but gets 50kW, the peak shaving fails.



2.3 Solar PV and Net Load Integration



If the customer has onsite generation, the relevant variable is Net Load.





$$P_{net}(t) = P_{load}(t) - P_{PV}(t)$$



The AI must ingest Solar Irradiance Forecasts (GHI/DNI) to predict the Net Load.

Clear_Sky_Index: A ratio of actual irradiance to theoretical clear-sky irradiance. This helps the AI distinguish between "nighttime" (predictable zero) and "cloud cover" (stochastic drop). High intermittency requires a higher reserve buffer in the battery.12



2.4 Data Preprocessing and Cleansing



Raw interval data is rarely model-ready.

Resampling: If the meter data is 5-minute but the demand charge is 15-minute, the data must be resampled (averaged) to 15 minutes. Optimizing at 5-minute resolution for a 15-minute charge leads to "over-shaving" (wasting energy on short spikes that would naturally average out).14

Imputation: Missing intervals should be filled via linear interpolation (for short gaps) or "same-day-last-week" substitution (for long gaps) to prevent the AI from interpreting a data outage as a "zero load" opportunity to charge.



3. Forecasting Modules: The Eyes of the System



To stop "shaving all day," the system needs to anticipate the magnitude and timing of the day's peak relative to the rest of the month. This requires a hierarchical forecasting architecture.



3.1 Short-Term Load Forecasting (STLF)



This module predicts the load profile for the next $H$ hours (Rolling Horizon).

Architecture: Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks are the industry standard for time-series forecasting due to their ability to capture long-range dependencies (e.g., the thermal inertia of a building).15

Target Variable: Net Load ($kW$) at 15-minute resolution.

Input Window: Past 24-168 hours of load, temperature, and day-type.

Loss Function: The model should prioritize Peak Magnitude Accuracy over general Mean Squared Error (MSE). A standard MSE loss treats an error at 3 AM (low load) the same as an error at 3 PM (peak load).

Custom Loss: Weighted MSE where weights are proportional to the load magnitude: $L = \sum w_t (y_t - \hat{y}_t)^2$, where $w_t = 1 + \alpha \cdot (y_t / \max(y))$.



3.2 Peak Probability Classification (The "Trigger")



Instead of just predicting kW, a secondary model should predict the probability that the current day will set a monthly peak.

Architecture: Random Forest or Gradient Boosting (XGBoost) classifier.17

Binary Output: Is Today A Peak Day? (Yes/No).

Logic:

If $P(Peak) < Threshold$: Enter Conservation Mode. Maintain high SoC, perform only shallow arbitrage. Do not shave load.

If $P(Peak) > Threshold$: Enter Peak Shaving Mode. Pre-charge to 100% before the window.

Correction: This specific logic gate prevents the "shave all day" error by disabling the shaving function entirely on days identified as non-critical.19



4. Mathematical Formulation: Giving the AI the "Math"



The user explicitly asked to "give it the math." Whether implementing a deterministic solver (MILP) or training a stochastic agent (RL), the fundamental mathematical formulation of the optimization problem is identical. The core challenge is linearizing the non-continuous "Max" function of the demand charge.



4.1 Mixed-Integer Linear Programming (MILP) Formulation



This formulation defines the theoretical optimum. It should be used to generate training data for the AI (Imitation Learning) or as the core logic in a Model Predictive Control (MPC) wrapper.20

Objective Function:

Minimize the total cost $J$ over the horizon $T$:

$$ \min J = \sum_{t=1}^{T} \left( C_{energy}(t) \cdot P_{grid}(t) \cdot \Delta t \right) + C_{demand} \cdot P_{peak} + \sum_{t=1}^{T} C_{deg}(P_{batt}(t)) $$

Where:

$P_{grid}(t)$: Power drawn from the grid at time $t$.

$C_{demand}$: Demand charge rate ($\$/kW$).

$P_{peak}$: A decision variable representing the maximum billing demand for the month.

$C_{deg}$: Battery degradation cost per kWh.

Constraints:

Peak Definition (Linearization):To minimize $P_{peak}$, we constrain it to be greater than or equal to the grid load at every time step. The solver, seeking to minimize cost, will squeeze $P_{peak}$ down until it rests on the single highest load point.13$$P_{peak} \ge P_{grid}(t) \quad \forall t \in \{1, \dots, T\}$$

Ratchet / Peak-So-Far Constraint:This is the mathematical fix for the "shaving all day" error. We constrain the solution such that $P_{peak}$ cannot be lower than the peak already observed in the past.$$P_{peak} \ge P_{max\_observed}$$

Effect: If the facility already hit 500 kW on Day 1, and today is Day 15 with a forecasted max of 450 kW, this constraint makes $P_{peak}$ a fixed constant (500 kW) in the optimization. The marginal value of reducing the 450 kW load to 400 kW becomes zero in the demand charge term. The solver will effectively "turn off" peak shaving (unless energy arbitrage justifies it), preventing battery waste.8

Power Balance:$$P_{grid}(t) = P_{load}(t) - P_{batt\_dis}(t) + P_{batt\_ch}(t)$$

Energy Continuity (SoC):$$E(t+1) = E(t) + P_{batt\_ch}(t) \eta_{ch} \Delta t - \frac{P_{batt\_dis}(t) \Delta t}{\eta_{dis}}$$

Capacity Limits:$$E_{min} \le E(t) \le E_{max}$$$$0 \le P_{batt\_ch}(t) \le P_{converter\_max}$$$$0 \le P_{batt\_dis}(t) \le P_{converter\_max}$$



4.2 Terminal Constraints for Rolling Horizon



Since we cannot solve for the whole month at once (forecast accuracy degrades), we solve for a 24-48 hour horizon. However, a short horizon can lead to "greedy" depletion.

Terminal Energy Constraint: $E(T) \ge E_{reserve}$. Forces the battery to end the day with enough energy to handle tomorrow's predicted volatility.

Terminal Peak Cost: Add a cost term to the objective function representing the expected future value of the peak.



5. Reinforcement Learning (RL): The Adaptive Controller



While MILP is powerful, it is brittle to forecast errors. Reinforcement Learning (RL) creates a robust policy that maps states to actions, learning to manage risk implicitly.



5.1 The Sparse Reward Problem



The central difficulty in training RL for peak shaving is Sparse Rewards. The agent only sees the "Demand Charge" penalty once a month. For the other 29 days, the feedback loop is broken.

Symptom: The agent acts randomly or optimizes only for the dense reward (energy arbitrage), leading to "shaving all day."



5.2 Reward Shaping Strategy



To fix this, we must construct a Synthetic Reward Function that provides feedback at every time step $t$.23



$$R_t = R_{energy} + R_{peak\_tracking} + R_{degradation}$$

Peak Tracking Reward:$$R_{peak\_tracking} = - \lambda_{penalty} \cdot \max(0, P_{grid}(t) - P_{max\_so\_far})$$

Mechanism: This term punishes the agent immediately and heavily whenever it allows the grid load to exceed the "watermark" set by previous days. This creates a continuous "electric fence" around the current peak.25

Degradation Cost (The Idle Incentive):$$R_{degradation} = - C_{wear} \cdot |P_{batt}(t)|$$

Mechanism: By imposing a small cost on every action, the agent learns that doing nothing (Idling) is better than doing something low-value. This is the direct cure for "shaving all day." If the arbitrage spread or peak reduction value doesn't exceed $C_{wear}$, the optimal action is to sit still.26



5.3 Algorithm Selection: Soft Actor-Critic (SAC)



For battery control, Soft Actor-Critic (SAC) is the recommended algorithm over DQN or PPO.27

Continuous Action Space: SAC outputs a continuous value (e.g., "Discharge 34.5 kW") rather than discrete steps ("Discharge 30kW" or "40kW"). This precision is vital for hitting exact peak targets without under-shaving or over-discharging.

Entropy Regularization: SAC encourages exploration, preventing the agent from getting stuck in a local optimum (e.g., "never discharge") early in training.



6. Coincident Peak (CP) Strategies



In jurisdictions like ERCOT (4CP), PJM (5CP), or IESO (Global Adjustment), the demand charge is based on the grid's peak, not the customer's. This requires a fundamentally different logic path.



6.1 Data Requirements for CP



The customer's internal load data is irrelevant for predicting the CP event (though relevant for managing it). The AI must ingest:

ISO/RTO Load Forecasts: API feeds from the grid operator (e.g., PJM Data Miner).

Grid-Scale Weather: Temperature forecasts for major load centers (e.g., Dallas/Houston for ERCOT 4CP).



6.2 "All-In" Dispatch Logic



When a CP event is probable, the objective function shifts from "Efficiency" to "Maximum Impact."

Threshold: If $Forecast_{ISO} > P_{threshold}$ (e.g., top 1% of historical loads), trigger CP Mode.

Action: Discharge at maximum rated power ($P_{max}$) regardless of building load (up to the point of zero net export, unless export is compensated).

Probabilistic Dispatch: Since CP timing is uncertain, the AI uses a "Shotgun Approach," discharging during the probable 3-4 hour window. The cost of "wasting" a cycle on a false alarm is negligible compared to the risk of missing the CP event, which can cost hundreds of dollars per kW.29



7. Battery Degradation and Life Cycle Management



A BESS is a depreciating asset. Every cycle consumes a portion of its finite life. The "shaving all day" behavior is not just operationally inefficient; it is financially destructive.



7.1 Degradation Physics



Cycle Aging: Caused by the mechanical stress of lithium ions intercalating into the anode/cathode. Proportional to throughput and Depth of Discharge (DoD).

Calendar Aging: Caused by parasitic chemical reactions, accelerated by high State of Charge (SoC) and temperature.



7.2 Cost Integration



To prevent "busy work," the AI needs a Hurdle Rate.





$$Cost_{throughput} = \frac{\text{Battery Replacement Cost}}{\text{Total Lifetime Energy Throughput}}$$



Example:

Cost: $\$500/kWh_{cap}$

Life: 4000 cycles

Throughput Cost $\approx \$0.06/kWh$.

If the AI attempts to shave a load spike that saves only $\$0.04/kWh$ in demand charges (because it’s a non-peak day), the equation $Savings - Cost_{throughput}$ becomes negative. The optimizer will correctly choose to Idle. This mathematical "friction" is the mechanism that stops continuous discharging.30



8. Implementation Guide



To implement this correctly using the Python ecosystem:

Optimization Engine: Use Pyomo or PuLP to build the MILP formulation described in Section 4. Connect it to a solver like CBC (open source) or Gurobi (commercial).

Why? Symbolic modeling allows you to explicitly write the constraint model.peak >= model.grid_import[t].

Forecasting: Use TensorFlow or PyTorch to build the LSTM models.

Why? Deep learning libraries handle the complex sequence data of load profiles.

Data Pipeline: Use Pandas for resampling interval data (e.g., df.resample('15T').mean()) and Scikit-Learn for preprocessing (scaling).



Summary of the Fix



The transition from "shaving all day" to "intelligent peaking" requires:

Awareness: Ingesting "Peak-So-Far" and "Billing Cycle Progress" features.

Valuation: Implementing a "Peak Tracking" reward function that punishes new maximums.

Friction: Adding degradation costs to penalize low-value discharging.

Math: Using MILP or Shaped RL to linearize the max-function and optimize for the billing determinant, not just energy volume.

By feeding the AI these specific mathematical constraints and data features, it will naturally converge on the optimal strategy: periods of dormancy punctuated by decisive, high-power discharges during the critical monthly peak intervals.

SECTION 1 — PURPOSE OF THE FINANCIAL MODEL

1.1 Purpose This manual defines the financial equations, lifecycle cost models, incentive logic, rate-structure modeling, degradation-adjusted economics, loan structures, and AI behavioral rules required to evaluate the economic performance of a commercial battery energy storage system (BESS). The purpose is to give AI a deterministic, engineering-accurate financial framework that:

Calculates savings correctly Determines cashflow impacts Evaluates incentives Runs NPV, IRR, and payback properly Prevents inflated or impossible financial outcomes Explains results clearly

1.2 Audience This manual is designed for use inside an AI-enabled energy modeling tool supporting: Sales teams Engineers DR aggregators ESCO modelers Finance partners

1.3 Modeling Requirements The financial engine must: Use deterministic formulas Respect technical limits from PDF #1 and #2 Enforce tariff rules Enforce incentive rules Avoid double-counting Adjust cashflows for degradation Handle loan structures correctly Apply discount rates consistently Report uncertainty transparently



SECTION 2 — COMPONENTS OF ANNUAL SAVINGS

2.1 Annual Savings Annual savings come from five major categories:

Demand charge savings Arbitrage savings Demand response revenue Tariff migration value Operational improvements (HVAC interactions optional)

Annual savings must be reduced by: Degradation losses O&M expenses Cycle penalties (if used) Loan repayment (in financed scenarios)

2.2 Demand Charge Savings Demand charges are based on the highest peak demand in the billing cycle, not multiple periods.

DemandSavings = PeakReduction × DemandCharge × 12

Where PeakReduction is determined from the peak-shaving model.

AI must never allow demand savings from multiple TOU categories.

2.3 Arbitrage Savings Arbitrage revenue:

ArbitrageSavings = Delivered_kWh_per_day × 365 × (PeakRate − OffPeakRate)

Constraints: Spread must be positive Battery must recharge Cycles per day must be below warranty limits

AI must not assume arbitrage in multiple periods.

2.4 Demand Response Revenue DRRevenue = CommittedKW × EventHours × NumEvents × ProgramRate

If DR includes capacity payments: CapacityPayment = CommittedKW × MonthlyRate × 12

AI must model DR conflicts with arbitrage and shaving.

2.5 Tariff Migration Savings Tariff migration occurs when battery enables a more favorable tariff.

SECTION 3 — COST STRUCTURE: CAPEX, OPEX, FINANCING

3.1 Total CAPEX Components AI must sum:

3.2 Operating Expenses Annual operating costs include:

EMS software license Ongoing monitoring Preventative maintenance Insurance Lifecycle replacement accrual Performance testing Battery augmentation (if needed)

3.3 Cycle Degradation Cost Batteries lose capacity through cycling. A cycle cost can be included:

CycleCost = ReplacementCost / (ExpectedCycleLife)

3.4 Replacement Cost If analysis horizon exceeds battery life (e.g., 10-year analysis, 7-year life), AI must apply replacement cost:

ReplacementCost occurs in Year_LifeEnd DiscountedReplacement = ReplacementCost / (1 + r)^(LifeEnd)

4.1 Simple Payback simple_payback = NetCAPEX / NetAnnualSavings

Where NetCAPEX = CAPEX − incentives.

AI must: Reject payback if NetAnnualSavings ≤ 0 Warn if payback > analysis horizon Reject payback if NetCAPEX ≤ 0 without modeling incentives properly

4.2 Discounted Payback discounted_payback = smallest t where Σ(NetAnnualSavings / (1+r)^t) ≥ NetCAPEX

4.3 Loan-Adjusted Payback When financed:

LoanPayback = TotalLoanPayments / NetAnnualSavings

Loan payments must replace CAPEX in numerator.

AI must not combine both methods.

5.1 NPV Definition NPV = −NetCAPEX + Σ(NetAnnualSavings_t / (1 + r)^t)

Where: t = year r = discount rate //must never be negative

5.2 Discount Rate Selection Typical values: Commercial: 6–10% Industrial: 8–15% Risk-heavy DR: 12–20%

If discount rate missing: AI must request clarification.

5.3 Degradation-Adjusted Savings NetAnnualSavings must decline as battery degrades:

NetAnnualSavings_t = DemandSavings_t + ArbitrageSavings_t + DRRevenue_t − OandM_t − DegradationCost_t

Degradation impacts: usable_kWh usable_kW efficiency cycle performance

5.4 NPV Red Flags AI Must Catch NPV > 3 × CAPEX → suspected modeling error NPV negative but IRR high → error NPV positive but payback > analysis horizon → mismatched assumptions



SECTION 6 — INTERNAL RATE OF RETURN (IRR)

6.1 IRR Formula Solve r such that: 0 = −NetCAPEX + Σ(NetAnnualSavings_t / (1+r)^t)

AI must solve with numerical iteration.

6.2 IRR Validity IRR must lie between −100% and +100%. If outside → invalid.

6.3 Cases IRR Fails Negative savings first years Multiple sign changes Non-monotonic cashflows

SECTION 9 — FEDERAL INVESTMENT TAX CREDIT (ITC) MODELING

9.1 Purpose of ITC Modeling The Investment Tax Credit is one of the most influential financial incentives for battery storage. ITC eligibility rules are strict and depend heavily on charging-source requirements. AI must enforce all IRS rules and avoid any incorrect tax assumptions.

9.2 ITC Eligibility AI must check the following conditions:

If battery charges more than 75 percent from renewable generation (typically solar) → ITC eligible If battery is grid-charged more than 25 percent → ITC reduced or disallowed If battery is standalone without renewable pairing → not ITC eligible under standard rules (unless falling under new IRA provisions) If battery participates in arbitrage using grid power → ITC may be impacted

AI must never assume ITC eligibility based solely on presence of battery.

9.3 ITC Basis ITC_basis = TotalCAPEX − disallowed_incentives − grants − rebates

SGIP may reduce basis depending on classification. Utility incentives sometimes reduce basis.

AI must: Remove any grant-type incentive from basis Keep performance-based incentives untouched (they do not affect basis)

9.4 ITC Calculation ITC_amount = ITC_basis × ITC_rate

Where ITC_rate may be: 30 percent (base) +10 percent (domestic content) +10 percent (energy community) Up to 50 percent with stackable adders

9.5 Depreciation Interaction ITC reduces MACRS depreciation by half the ITC rate.

DepreciableBasis = ITC_basis × (1 − ITC_rate/2)

SalvageValue / (1+r)^N
